verses.text: It pleased Darius to appoint over the kingdom one hundred twenty satraps, who would be in charge throughout the whole realm.
verses.comment: Darius restructures the administration of Babylon. The satraps serve as provincial governors.

verses.text: Over them he appointed three administrators, of whom Daniel was one, so that the satraps would be accountable to them and the king would not be harmed.
verses.comment: Daniel is elevated to leadership, a mark of God’s favor even in exile (see Dan. 2:48).

verses.text: Then Daniel distinguished himself above the administrators and satraps, because there was an excellent spirit in him, and the king planned to set him over the entire kingdom.
verses.comment: Daniel’s wisdom and character point to God’s guidance, prefiguring Christ’s sinless excellence (cf. Dan. 1:20, 5:12).

verses.text: Then the administrators and satraps sought to find a charge against Daniel concerning the kingdom; but they could find no fault or error, because he was faithful. No negligence or corruption was found in him.
verses.comment: Daniel’s blameless conduct foreshadows Christ, who was also found without guilt (see John 18:38).

verses.text: Then these men said, 'We will not find any charge against Daniel unless it is in connection with the law of his God.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s faithfulness to God becomes the target for accusation, paralleling later false charges against the saints (Acts 6:13).

verses.text: So the administrators and satraps came as a group before the king and said to him, 'King Darius, live forever!'
verses.comment: A customary greeting to the monarch, used when seeking favors (Dan. 2:4).

verses.text: All the administrators of the kingdom, the prefects, the satraps, the counselors, and the governors have agreed that the king should issue and enforce an edict: that anyone who prays to any god or man except you, O king, for thirty days, shall be thrown into the den of lions.
verses.comment: Like Nebuchadnezzar’s earlier decree (Dan. 3:6), this presents a conflict between divine and human law.

verses.text: Now, O king, issue the decree and put it in writing so that it cannot be changed, according to the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot be revoked.
verses.comment: The law of the Medes and Persians was irrevocable (see Esther 1:19), putting Daniel at legal risk.

verses.text: Therefore King Darius signed the written decree.
verses.comment: The irrevocable law is set in motion, as in similar situations (Esther 3:13).

verses.text: When Daniel learned that the decree had been signed, he went into his house. The windows in his upper room were open toward Jerusalem, and three times a day he knelt and prayed, giving thanks before his God, just as he had always done.
verses.comment: Daniel’s disciplined prayer life reflects Jewish custom (Ps. 55:17, 1 Kings 8:48) and prefigures the apostolic practice of regular prayer.

verses.text: Then these men came as a group and found Daniel praying and seeking favor before his God.
verses.comment: Daniel’s boldness in prayer is reminiscent of the apostles praying despite threats in Acts 16:13.

verses.text: So they approached the king and asked about the royal decree: 'Did you not sign an edict, saying that anyone who prays to any god or man except you, O king, for thirty days, would be thrown into the den of lions?' The king replied, 'The decree stands, according to the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot be revoked.'
verses.comment: The law’s immutability is reiterated, keeping Daniel’s fate seemingly sealed.

verses.text: Then they said to the king, 'Daniel, who is one of the captives from Judah, pays no attention to you, O king, or to the decree you signed, but continues to pray three times a day.'
verses.comment: Daniel is singled out as a foreign exile, highlighting his fidelity to God over state mandate (Dan. 1:6).

verses.text: When the king heard this, he was greatly distressed, and set his heart on delivering Daniel. Until sunset he labored to rescue him.
verses.comment: Darius’ struggle recalls Pilate’s inner conflict, both hesitating to condemn a righteous man (Matt. 27:19).

verses.text: But those men came as a group to the king and said to him, 'Remember, O king, that it is law of the Medes and Persians that no decree or order the king issues can be changed.'
verses.comment: The legal system here overrides the king’s mercy, showing human law’s limits before divine justice.

verses.text: So the king gave the order, and they brought Daniel and threw him into the lions’ den. The king said to Daniel, 'May your God, whom you serve continually, deliver you.'
verses.comment: Darius expresses hope in God’s power, echoing the faith of Daniel’s friends in Dan. 3:17 and God’s promise in Ps. 34:7.

verses.text: A stone was brought and laid over the opening of the den. The king sealed it with his own signet and those of his nobles so that nothing concerning Daniel might be changed.
verses.comment: The sealing of the stone foreshadows Christ’s tomb sealed by authorities (Matt. 27:66), hinting at resurrection themes.

verses.text: Then the king went to his palace and spent the night fasting, refusing entertainment, and sleep fled from him.
verses.comment: Darius’s fasting is parallel to believers interceding in distress (Acts 12:5).

verses.text: At the first light of dawn, the king arose and hurried to the lions’ den.
verses.comment: The early morning visit recalls the women going to Christ’s tomb at dawn (Matt. 28:1).

verses.text: When he came near the den, he called out to Daniel in anguish: 'Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God, whom you serve continually, been able to deliver you from the lions?'
verses.comment: Darius's appeal to God recognizes the living God, a key concept later in early church confessions.

verses.text: Then Daniel replied to the king, 'O king, live forever!'
verses.comment: Daniel’s response is both respectful and formal, adhering to royal protocol.

verses.text: 'My God sent his angel and shut the lions’ mouths, so that they have not hurt me, because I was found innocent before him; nor have I done any harm to you, O king.'
verses.comment: God’s deliverance by an angel prefigures recurring angelic interventions (Heb. 11:33). Daniel’s innocence before God points toward justification by grace.

verses.text: The king was exceedingly glad and ordered Daniel to be taken out of the den. And when Daniel was lifted from the den, no injury was found on him, because he had trusted in his God.
verses.comment: Like the fiery furnace episode (Dan. 3:27), Daniel is unharmed through faith and God’s protection (Ps. 91:2).

verses.text: At the king’s command, those men who accused Daniel were brought and thrown into the lions’ den, along with their wives and children. Before they reached the bottom of the den, the lions overpowered them and broke all their bones.
verses.comment: A divine reversal occurs: the wicked are punished and God’s justice is upheld. The severity reflects the seriousness of sin’s consequences.

verses.text: Then King Darius wrote to all the peoples, nations, and languages that live throughout all the earth: 'Peace be multiplied to you.'
verses.comment: A royal proclamation of peace, echoing the universal message found in later scripture (Luke 2:14).

verses.text: 'I decree that throughout all my royal dominion people are to tremble and fear before the God of Daniel. For he is the living God, enduring forever; his kingdom will never be destroyed, and his rule will never end.'
verses.comment: Darius’s confession anticipates the enduring kingdom Christ later establishes (Dan. 2:44; Ps. 145:13), hinting at the universal scope of God’s reign.

verses.text: 'He delivers and rescues; he works signs and wonders in heaven and on earth; he has saved Daniel from the power of the lions.'
verses.comment: God’s power to save and do wonders foreshadows the miracles and deliverance seen in Christ’s ministry (Acts 2:22).

verses.text: So Daniel prospered during the reign of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian.
verses.comment: Daniel's enduring success signals God’s ongoing providence. The movement from Darius to Cyrus marks a transition, setting the stage for restoration themes present elsewhere.
